actionplancommittee: Mamie Pepper, John Fireman and Peter Diah
actionplandescription: In recent time, the issue was raised before the F-CF and a committee of F-CF members was constituted to work with   local authorizes of Loyee town to address it. During the period under review, the committee, Mamie Pepper, John Fireman and Peter Diah mediated the dispute in collaboration with town authorities and the parties unanimously resolved to invite survey team to divide   the disputed area into equal parts for the two contenders within two weeks as of  July 13 meeting.
issuedescription:
Mr. John Fireman, a member of the Fleedin Community Forum who hails from Loyee town in Wee-Gbeyi District reported on a land dispute that exists between Jackson Karmore and John Tarpeh both of whom are citizens of Loyee Town.
This dispute, according to Mr. Fireman, had been on for over two years. Local leaders attempted several times to resolve it but failed.
In recent time, the issue was raised before the F-CF and a committee of F-CF members was constituted to work with   local authorizes of Loyee town to address it. During the period under review, the committee, Mamie Pepper, John Fireman and Peter Diah mediated the dispute in collaboration with town authorities and the parties unanimously resolved to invite survey team to divide   the disputed area into equal parts for the two contenders within two weeks as of  July 13 meeting.

actionplancommittee: To ensure that the referral is done in time, the K-DSC intervention committee headed by commissioner Tenty and whose membership includes BIN and the Kpaiblee Youth President was mandated to implement the solution by July 30, 2016.
actionplandescription:
The chairman concluded by calling on members of the Kpaiblee DSC to refer the issue to the CSC since indeed solution to this concern rests in the hands of authorities of GSM companies based in Monrovia.
To ensure that the referral is done in time, the K-DSC intervention committee headed by commissioner Tenty and whose membership includes BIN and the Kpaiblee Youth President was mandated to implement the solution by July 30, 2016.
issuedescription:
Mr. Peter Mahnmie, a clan chief and member of the Kpaiblee DSC reported to the joint session of the Kpaiblee DSC and Dubuzon CF in Old Yourpea Town on July 14, that while the GOL has responded to their long years of cry for better road condition through the MLDL Program, they still have a major challenge with lack of GSM coverage in the district. The clan chief emphasized that in the wake of any emergency, the population cannot quickly reach the police through mobile phone connectivity in almost all of the hugely populated towns of Kpaiblee District. 
In addressing himself to the issue raised by the clan chief, Kpaiblee District Commissioner and chairman of the K-DSC Alexander Tenty Jr.expressed the same concern and warned that the people of Kpaible District were at a serious security risk; especially owning to Kpaiblee’s strategic location along the Ivorian border where rebel incursion has taken place before.
issuename: Lack of GSM coverage in Kpaiblee District

actionplancommittee: Jefferson kwei D-CF Secretary, Justina Kwitti B-CF, Co-Chair and David Gee advisor.
actionplandescription:
CF members from the towns of Kahnblee and Gayeblee in Kpaiblee Administrative District reported to the Dubuzon CF that close to 15 armed men posting to be hunters are seen in the Kpaiblee forest by farmers on a daily basis.
 According to the two CF members who reported the issue, the presence of these armed men in the district is causing panic in the minds of the people thereby denying many farmers from going on their farm, especially women and children who may want to go on the farms unaccompanied.
They further said that is believed that these men are  from the neighboring district of Bu-Yao while there are speculations that some of them may have crossed from Neighboring  Ivory Coast
issuedescription:
A  CF member from Bah’s Town in Kpaiblee Administrative  District, Esther Bah reported to the  July 14 session of the Joint structure meeting that they are experiencing  strange movement of unknown armed  men from Gblor Clan, Doe Administrative District into the forest of Kpaiblee. They are said to be finding suitable sites for hunting expedition.
According to report, these men are seen late in the evening with shot guns heading for the mountainous areas of the region .The presence of these unknown individuals  is creating serious fear among the population of Kpaiblee District,as a result most people have abandoned their farms in frustration.
issuename: Strange movement of unknown armed men in Kpaiblee District.

actionplandescription: The CSC resolved on Monday, July 18 that LNP, BIN, NSA and County Inspector do a draft policy guideline to govern the regime of gun registration in Nimba.
issuedescription: Following several months of delay by NSC through the ministry of Internal Affairs to address out rightly the issue of proliferation of small arms in Nimba County, the Ministry of Internal Affairs has now authorized the county security council through the office of the chairman, Nimba County Superintendent Fong Zuagele to begin registration of guns in the county

actionplandescription:
The CSC in its July 18, 2016 sitting in Sanniquellie instructed the LNP commander for Nimba to transfer the check point from the Sanniquellie-Ganta highway to Walamon, a town believed to be the main conduit for smuggling.
The time line for transfer of the check point to Walamon is July 21, 2016 at 10am local time
issuedescription: In the May and June meetings of the CSC, LRA reported on the smuggling of some commodities from Guinea, especially motor cycles. Against this backdrop, the council resolved to erect a check point near Ganta on the road from Sanniquellie where most smugglers allegedly do pass to enter Ganta.But of late, it has been observed by citizens and some local government officials that the gate is being misused by LNP to collect money from travelers and decent business people

issuedescription: Bad road condition is experienced between Ziah Town and Boundary Town Since the civil war.
statusnotes: Bad road condition is experienced between Ziah Town and Boundary Town Since the civil war. The only road leading to Ziah town the capital of Konobo is damaging as a result of the heavy down pool of rain, again, heavy trucks are currently accessing the road to fetch cocoa products from the area. Light vehicle without 4 wheel gear or bad tires can’t access the road to Ziah town easily, some vehicle with even 4 wheel gear have to either stay a night on the road if the driver does not understand the road.  It mighty get worst if earth equipment do not pave the road before July to October 2016.

Gambling is mostly practiced in major citues. But the fact that is practiced in rural and poor communities is recipe for conflicts and family harmony. It breaks couples when men are lured by friends to take the venture and misapplied litlle financial and other resources of the familiy.

issuedescription:
The commissioner of Kpaiplay Town ship reported to the GG-DSC that the town chief of Loguatuo has been accused of lack of transparency and accountability in running the affairs of town. He appoints relatives to positions of trust without discussing with the town people
Mr Ama Worlea is been challenged by key stakeholders, including 9 members of the town who insist that Mr.Worlea be dismissed by the township commissioner of Kpanpla under whose jurisdiction the town chief falls.

actionplandescription: To successfully battle this outbreak, the GG-DSC leadership appointed a two man committee to meet with the Gbelay-Geh District Health and Agriculture coordinators on August 10. to discuss and strategize the way forward in containing the second  outbreak. The committee will report outcomes of the meeting on August 15 to the DSC leadership.
issuedescription:
In May and June, several communities in Gbelay-Geh District reported on an outbreak of animal disease that took the lives of over 100 goats, sheep and, pigs .This outbreak was contained by health authorities in the district. They, at that time, advised domesticated animal owners to isolate their sick animals to allow animal disease vaccinators to treat surviving animal in the affected areas, 
During the August 1 meeting, the district commissioner, of Gbelay-Geh Mr. John Quato reported another outbreak of animal disease in over ten communities including major towns like Zorta-pa, Zorlepula, Younlay,Sakolay and Goguatuo losing about 50 animals in each town.
issuename: Another Outbreak of animal disease in Gbelay-Geh Dist.

actionplancommittee: DSC members, Raymond Tomah, Etta Dahn,Varkaba Kromah,Mark Tomah and Bill Yeaney
actionplandescription: In an attempt to resolve this dispute, the DSC leadership constituted a five man committee comprising of DSC members, Raymond Tomah, Etta Dahn,Varkaba Kromah,Mark Tomah and Bill Yeaney to mediate. 1.	The committee  for the action point  on Abuse  of Freedom  of the Press  in Gbelay-Geh, District, commissioners John Quato,Winpea Sandi and Zahn Dakerneh  reported to the GG-DSC & G-CF  joint structure meeting in Garplay on August 1 that the planned meeting with the management of Radio Karn Voice Peace(RKVP)  was held on July 18  to discuss the issue of political opponents castigating each other  on  RKVP.The station management  acknowledged the concern  and promised to put in place a policy  that will regulate behavior of individuals appearing on  the radio henceforth.
One of the measures indicated by the management is to do one week radio announcement in English and the local vernaculars calling on individuals wishing to buy air time be admonished   to focus on the issues under discussion and not personalities

issuedescription:
3.	In May and June, several communities in Gbelay-Geh District reported on an outbreak of animal disease that took the lives of over 100 goats, sheep and, pigs .This outbreak was contained by health authorities in the district. They, at that time, advised domesticated animal owners to isolate their sick animals to allow animal disease vaccinators to treat surviving animal in the affected areas, 
During the August 1 meeting, the district commissioner, of Gbelay-Geh Mr. John Quato reported another outbreak of animal disease in over ten communities including major towns like Zorta-pa, Zorlepula, Younlay,Sakolay and Goguatuo losing about 50 animals in each town.
issuename: Another outbreak of animal disease in Gbelay-Geh District

issuedescription: A resident of Boi Town in Zorzor District, Yarkpazuo Thomas, fired a 65yrs old woman known as Krubo Sumo Yougie with a single barrow gun leaving her badly wounded. She was immediately taken to Curran Lutheran Hospital in Zorzor and later referred to Tellewoyan Hospital in Voinjama, where she was pronounced dead upon arrival. The allege culprit escaped after the act  but was arrested three days later, charged  and subsequently sent to court.
issuename: The murder of a 65yrs old woman in  Boi Town, Zozor District

statusnotes: Perpetrator was arrested, charged and currently behind bar awaiting trial. So, issue is resolved.

actionplandescription: Elevate issue to NSC
issuedescription: Residents of Kudu Town, Foya District have complained of being denied by Guineans access and usage of Mankona River sand along that border line. The Kudu residents say the Makona River sand had been a source of their livelihoods, and   they have over the years been using said resources to do construction works in their community and its environs. They are calling on government to immediately intervene in order to alleviate suffering this deprivation will cause them.
issuename: Denial of Liberians in Kudu, Foya District by Guineans access & usage  of Mankon River sand
issuenotes: CSC needs to keep calling on NSC to really pioratize this issue
statusnotes: The issue has elevated to NSC in July and will again be re-flagged in August

actionplandescription: Do more awareness and institute measure that will regulate movement of children at nights
issuedescription: School going / underage children most of whom often heavily intoxicated are regularly been seen in the street of Voinjama after 11:00PM. There are growing fear that some of them could be exploited, assaulted or even killed. MOYS is calling on government to institute measures that will regulate children movement at night and their access to entertainment centers.
issuename: Vulnerability of children in the street of Voinjama
issuenotes: Follow up needs to be made to MoGC&SP regarding the status of the issue
statusnotes: This issue will be handled by MoGC&SP as soon as possible

issuedescription: It has been widely observed that some civilians, mainly boys have engaged in the usage of security uniforms in Foya and it environs. Security personnel are concern that some of these violators could cause problem in the community and the public could cast the blame on them. There is also a growing fear that some of these violators are maybe using these uniforms to intimidate, do rubbery or carry out harassment in Foya or the surrounding communities.
issuename: Civilians using security uniforms in Foya and its environs
issuenotes: Was the public awareness or sensitization done in the community and on the radio?
statusnotes: Currently undergoing security surveillance

actionplandescription: Collect information on the varoius location and effects and submit findings to the CSC for intervention
actionplannotes: Setting committees is good, unfortunately issues drag on for months without committees acting instead they present excuses why they coud not perform their task.
issuedescription: Army worms invasion is a regular phenomenon in Bong County. In 2007-8, it took place in three districts Zota, Suakoko, and Panta. it ravage crops,  polluted streams of water and caused diseases to the population and mostly women and children. Little is known on whether the Government or local authorities have put in place an action plan for long term combat and eradication.
issuename: Invasion of army worms in Kpaai district
issuenotes:
Following the army worms invasion, how does the population cope with it? Which are the local solution to the problem. How does the national governemnt react to the invasion? who are those most affected and is there any reparation or any form of assistancw for the victims?
Does the local population have any information on these pests that could help them protect themselves?
statusnotes: Invasion of army worms has been noted in Bong County since 2007-8. These pests invade farms aound July August each year. GOL / FAO have made efforts in the past to eradicate the pest but little is known on whether the MOA has any sustainable plan and localized technics for combating or preventing the army worms invasion

actionplandescription: To generate 150USD for machine repair as quickly as possible and bring machine back to Voinjama from the field ASAP
issuedescription: The Lofa County yellow machine (caterpillar) was taken to the field by the County Inspector to do some community work for communities in Quardu – Gboni District nearly seven months ago. After the community work and while the machine was coming back to Voinjama, it broke-down in Balakpalasu and has not gotten repaired since then. The machine has been packed and abandoned in Balakpalasu for over six months thereby attracting criminal to take advantage. At the moment, it is believed that some parts of the machine have already been extracted by criminals and CSC are furus with the County Inspector for abandoning the machine in the field.
issuename: Abandonment of Lofa County Yellow Machine (caterpillar) in the field rendering it vulnerable to criminals
statusnotes: Generating funding for machine repair

issuedescription: A member of the Ganta Community Forum, Mr. Oliver Suah reported at the August 5 meeting in Ganta that despite the closure of the crossing point over St. John River between Nimba and Bong Counties near the town of Gowee on the Nimba side of the river by Bain-Garr District authorities, unknown individuals are reported to be secretly crossing travelers to and fro Bong County overnight. This, according to the report, resulted to the drowning of a citizen of Bain-Garr District on July 29, 2016.

The CF intervention committee was mandated to oversee the referral in three days.
issuedescription:
Several Ganta CF members from Neigbeh and Domapa Communities reported to the August 5  session of the Bain-Garr DSC and Ganta CF joint  monthly meeting that travelers from Guinea,Ivory Coast and other parts of Nimba County are seen late hours in Neigbeh and Domapa communities boarding vehicles after by-passing the BIN check point on motor bikes.
The CF members in those communities hold the suspicion that these travelers may be evading GOL taxes or are carrying illegal substances to Monrovia which in their view poses security threat.
issuename: Alliens evade security checks at Ganta BIN gate.

actionplandescription: The committee’s fact finding result proved that these armed men were hunters from Gblor Clan in the Boe-Quella Administrative District.Following the establishment of this fact, the district commissioner of Kpaiblee District led an array of local government officials to meet with their counterpart in Boe-Quella to discuss the issue. At the end of the visit, it was resolved that hunters from Boe-Quella desist from entering the forest of Kpaiblee District without prior permission from the people of Kpaiblee District.
issuedescription: In July, CF members reported that farmers see fifteen armed men in the Kpaiblee forest on a daily basis making citizens afraid to go to the farms; in particular women and children will not go unaccompanied. The Dubuzon CF leadership appointed a three-member committee to conduct a fact-finding mission.
issuename: 15 armed men seen in Kpaiblee Forest

actionplancommittee: Paramount Chief Henry Kenneh leads the committee with two other members. Marie Yeleyon and Peter P.S.Paye.
actionplandescription:
This situation claimed the attention of people of   the nearby towns with fear that the September 2015 experience could be repeated if steps are not taken timely to address the action of the ferry operators.
To appropriately address this concern, the W-DSC has taken the following actions:
1.	Constitute a committee to sensitize people of the district on the capacity of the ferry
2.	Erect a bill board at the crossing point with inscription of the ferry’s loading capacity
3.	Replace operators
These actions are expected to take effect before next structure meeting in September.
Paramount Chief Henry Kenneh leads the committee with two other members. Marie Yeleyon and Peter P.S.Paye.
issuedescription:
It can be recalled that in September of 2015,a ferry used by the people of Wee-Gbeyi District over the Weer Creek which separates the district into half capsized due to over loading leaving three dead and many properties destroyed.
MLDL Program supported the Wee-Gbeyi DSC leadership with feeding and compensation for divers to recover the dead bodies from the river. Following this episode, the chairman of the Wee-Gbeyi DSC, Mr. Jefferson Gokor appealed to the Vice President (VP) of Liberia, Amb.Joseph N. Boakia for assistance to reconstruct the ferry. The VP responded with US3, 000-00.The DSC constructed a ferry with capacity to hold 30 passengers. Of late, operators of the ferry have begun to load close to fifty passengers to the detriment of the travelers.
This situation claimed the attention of people of   the nearby towns with fear that the September 2015 experience could be repeated if steps are not taken timely to address the action of the ferry operators.

Farm Land Dispute-A farm land dispute was reported to the Bonlah CF by Mr. Bill Dolo on August 3, 2016 during the regular monthly meeting of the joint structures of Yarmein DSC and Bonlah CF.Mr. Dolo accused one Christopher Torlon of destroying his rubber farm by cutting down several trees and sold portion of his farm land to other people in the community.

issuedescription:
Passengers on a single motor bike including pregnant women, little children and goods while the rider sits on the gas tank of the bike.
The behavior of the bike riders had over the last few months resulted into lost   of precious lives and properties.
The W-DSC, following deliberations on the issue with inputs from cross section of the membership, resolved to prevail on Police authorities in Saclepea to conduct one day workshop for bike riders in the district for awareness raising on the danger of overloading and high speeding of bikes. 
A three member committee comprising of Saclepea City Mayor, Marie Yeleyon, Civil society activist, Peter P.S. Paye and Elder O. Gonkewon Karnue was constituted to work with the Saclepea Police to organize the awareness raising workshop in Saclepea City within three weeks as of the date of this structure meeting.
Wee-Gbeyi DSC:
It can be recalled that in September of 2015,a ferry used by the people of Wee-Gbeyi District over the Weer Creek which separates the district into half capsized due to over loading leaving three dead and many properties destroyed.
MLDL Program supported the Wee-Gbeyi DSC leadership with feeding and compensation for divers to recover the dead bodies from the river. Following this episode, the chairman of the Wee-Gbeyi DSC, Mr. Jefferson Gokor appealed to the Vice President (VP) of Liberia, Amb.Joseph N. Boakia for assistance to reconstruct the ferry. The VP responded with US3, 000-00.The DSC constructed a ferry with capacity to hold 30 passengers. Of late, operators of the ferry have begun to load close to fifty passengers to the detriment of the travelers.
This situation claimed the attention of people of   the nearby towns with fear that the September 2015 experience could be repeated if steps are not taken timely to address the action of the ferry operators.
To appropriately address this concern, the W-DSC has taken the following actions:
1.	Constitute a committee to sensitize people of the district on the capacity of the ferry
2.	Erect a bill board at the crossing point with inscription of the ferry’s loading capacity
3.	Replace operators
These actions are expected to take effect before next structure meeting in September.
Paramount Chief Henry Kenneh leads the committee with two other members. Marie Yeleyon and Peter P.S.Paye.
Yarmein DSC
Update of July action points
With reference to the issue of damaged Kan bridge in Yarmein District earlier elevated to the N-CSC, the CSC disclosed plan for the temporary rehabilitation of the bridge to serve the people during the rainy season. The plan is to use some rail beans from Arcelor Mittal company to construct the temporary bridge before the end of August, 2016.
The N-CSC also informed the committee that US79, 000 dollars has been approved from the county social development fund to reconstruct a permanent bridge over Kan bridge in November, 2016.
New issues raised at the Yarmein DSC and Bonlah CF August 3 meeting
Bonlah CF
Public Health and Safety Issue-CF members from four communities in Yarmein District reported in the August 3 meeting in Gbeleyee that youths of their towns are engaged in the miss- use and sale of narcotic drugs. The report stated that under the influence of  the drugs, many young people are  committing crimes ranging from attempted rapes,thieft of property, fighting with others  and money doubling
Considering  the gravity of this issue, the leadership of  the Bonlah CF constituted  three man committee to have the said issue  referred to the district security council. Those appoint on the committee are: 
Shad rick Norkeh, Angeline Yeke and Emmanuel Z. Larkpor.
Bonlah CF
Farm Land Dispute-A member of the Yarmein District Security Council, Mr.  Othello Zomonway who represents the Traditional Council of Chiefs and Elders on the DSC reported to the Bonlah CF leadership a land dispute that exists between him and Mr. Augustus Gballah of New Yekepa Town.
In his well worded one sheet communication addressed to the forum Mr. Zomonway accused Augustus of brushing down 11 trees of rubber on the farm while in the process of extending his farm deep into Mr. Zomonway’s land Mr. Zomonway asserted that local town chiefs of Kanlah and New Yekepa towns have tried to settle this matter but to n avail due to Mr.Gballah’s intransigence. 
Mr. Zomonway concluded in his  letter that he has no other alternatives but to request the intervention of the Bonlah CF.
In an effort to resolve the issue, the leadership of the Bonlah CF mandated its intervention committee to mediate the dispute beginning August 5, 2016.
Of the seven member mediation committee, three were named to do the mediation. Those appointed are:
1.	Tongor  Dolo
2.	Sam Korto
3.	Alex Gorpu
The committee outcomes of its work on September 7, 2016 in Gbeleyee.

Yarmein DSC
Illegal planting of crops in Acerlor Mittal’s mining concession area-The community services manager of the world’s giant steel company, Acerlor Mittal-Liberia Limited, Mr Vannie Kiazulu reported to the Yarmein District Security Council in its August 3 meeting held in Gbeleyee that farmers from several communities in Yarmein Administrative District have begun planting rubber, cocoa, coffee and Palm on the legally certificated mining areas of Acerlor Mittal. The communities include:
1.	Bonlah
2.	Lugbeyee
3.	Gbeleyee Kanlah Gbarpa
4.	Camp 4 and 
5.	Barpa
As a way of addressing the concern of the company, the leadership of the Y-DSC appointed a committee comprising of Camp 4 Township Commissioner, George P. Nyeneken, Paramount Chiefs Cooper Walaka and Richard Gbantea and Youth representative Thomas Gonotee to meet leaders of the afford mentioned communities to raise awareness on the legal implications involved in trespassing on other persons’ property. The committee will begin visitations to the communities on August 26, 2016 and submit reports on September 7, 2016

actionplandescription: Considering the alarming rate of the occurrence of these attacks on the properties and personal effects of citizens of Bu-Yao District, the Gblourlay CF deemed it expedient to elevate the issue to the Bu-Yao DSC for its prompt intervention since it has security actors who are clothed with the authority to fight crimes.
issuedescription:
Leaders of several communities in Bu-Yao District have reported through their respective CF representatives that criminal activities are on the increase in the district since the beginning of July. Key activities of the alleged criminals are stealing of domestic animals such as goats, chickens, pigs, sheep and cows. Some are also in the business of home braking for personal effects of people in the town.
Communities seriously affected by these  criminal hits are;
1.	Yao-Mahnplay
2.	Tahnplay
3.	,Tiahplay
4.	,Yao-Lepula
5.	,Beeplay
issuename: Criminal activities on the increase nin Bu-Yao

The two CF members are:
1.	John Granda
2.	Joseph Vankah

actionplandescription: In order to formalize the understanding reached during the Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) process as initiated by the joint mediation committee of the Gbelay-Geh DSC and Garplay CF and mentored and supported  by the MLDL program in Garplay  town between the people of Loelay  and Vayenglay  towns, the above- mentioned parties resolved in November 2015  to enter into an agreement (this MOU ) that will consummate the final resolution of the dispute and obligate each party to the terms and conditions of this MOU.
mediationoutcome: Therefore the parties are agreed as follows; TEAMS AND CONDITIONS OF THE MOU  LOELAY TOWN The citizens of Loelay town through their ten man representation at the mediation agreed to;  1.	Drop all claims they have had against the people of Vayenglay town  2.	Resume inter-town visitations as it was before the conflict started.  3.	Rekindle the inter-marriage relationship that previously existed among them  4.	Attend ceremonies in each other’s town when invited.  5.	Climax the understanding reached with a traditional sacrifice in Loelay and Vayenglay  6.	Re-unite the youths  of the two towns through sporting activities  7.	Honor all provisions of the MOU without any pre-conditions. 8.	Establish seven man mounting committee to oversee the agreement for compliance VAYENGLAY TOWN  The citizens of Vayenglay town through their ten man representation at the mediation agreed to:                          1.	Drop all claims they have had against the people of Vayenglay town  2.	Resume inter-town visitations as it was the case  before the conflict started;   3.	Rekindle the inter-marriage relationship that previously existed among them  4.	Attend ceremonies in each other’s town when invited.  5.	Climax the understanding reached with a traditional sacrifice in Loelay and Vayenglay  6.	Re-unite the youths  of the two towns through sporting activities  7.	Accept the terms and conditions of the MOU in the spirit of unity and peaceful co- existence. 8.	Establish seven man mounting committee to oversee the agreement for compliance This Memorandum of Understanding becomes effective upon the day and date last signed by the authorized representative of the parties to this agreement and shall remain in full force and effect as long as Loelay and Vayenglay towns exist in Gbelay-Geh and Twah River Districts, Nimba County, Republic of Liberia. PENALTIES Any violator(S) of this agreement shall, without any pre-conditions pay the below listed items to the leaders of Loelay and Vayenglay towns within 72 hours:  1.	Two(2) matured rams (sheep) 2.	Two bags of 50kg  rice 3.	Ten thousand Liberian Dollars(LRD10,000) 4.	Two gallons of palm oil
issuedescription:
The Garplay Community Forum, in executing one of its mandates, detected and prioritized a volatile 15 years old conflict over claims and counter claims of disappearances of children and death of some adults as a result of alleged food poisoning, a   situation which if not resolved timely  could potentially erupt into a widespread community violence. These communities are located about 35 km from Loguatuo along the Centos river bank where Charles Taylor’s National Patriotic Front of Liberia established its first mayor training base in Gborplay and a subsequent incursion by Nimba Redemption Council(NRC) led by Karpeh Duanyen in the north of the district.
Considering the fragility of the region as it relates to the porosity of the border between Liberia and Cote d’ Ivoire, and the scarce presence of security personnel in this region and being cognizance of the fact that some unscrupulous individuals could explore any chaotic situation to unveil their anti-peace   agenda, the Garplay Community Forum deemed it necessary to request MLDL support in logistics and mentorship to mediate this  15 years- old dispute between the people of Loelay and Vayenglay towns.
issuename: Dispute over traditional beliefs between Loelay and Vayenglay

actionplancommittee: The DSC has therefore  charged the district commissioner and the DSC Secretary,Daaniel D Zekpeh and. Harris Katoe respectively  to effect the referral of their concern to the N-CSC in Sanniquellie  on September 5,2016
actionplandescription: In an attempt to seek lasting solution to this problem, the leadership of the Bu-Yao DSC has decided to elevate this concern to Nimba County Security Council with an appeal that the county road building machines be deployed in the district to recondition the Bahn-Butuo highway
issuedescription:
Citizens of Bu-Yao Administrative District have over the past few months have repeatedly reported to the Bu-Yao District Security Council about the deplorable road condition between Bahn and Butuo, the only major goods and service delivery route for the people of the district. This situation has  become  so alarming that going to  communities like Beeplay(district headquarters),Gblourlay(CF center) and Butuo township is now done by means of using  a long route through Toweh’s Town in Boe-Quella district consuming over five hours of travel, the report concluded.
In an attempt to seek lasting solution to this problem, the leadership of the Bu-Yao DSC has decided to elevate this concern to Nimba County Security Council with an appeal that the county road building machines be deployed in the district to recondition the Bahn-Butuo highway.

actionplancommittee: Mr. D. Harris Kartoe, DSC secretary
actionplandescription:
Realizing that the B-DSC does not have the authority to do assignments of security officers in districts, has resolved to prompt the N-CSC to do everything legally possible to assign some BIN, LDEA and LNP to the district before the end of this year
The B-DSC also instructed Mr. D. Harris Kartoe, DSC secretary to communicate this concern with N-CSC for their timely invention. The communication is expected to be delivered to the N-CSC in Sanniquellie on September 5, 2016.
issuedescription:

issuedescription:
The Gblourlay Community Forum has received report of a land dispute between Sam Monque and Ma-Larto, both of Nyor-Gbanwea Town in Bu-Yao District.

issuedescription:
Security actors on the Bain-Garr DSC have expressed the concern that the Ganta BIN check point on the Ganta-Gbarnga highway is now engulf by residential communities thereby making it difficult for security personnel to determine whether those passing the point are residents of the check point community or travelers. This, according to the report is impeding security operations at the check point.
This concern has therefore been referred to the N-CSC with recommendation that the check point be relocated to St. John River between Bong and Nimba Counties.

issuedescription: Many Elementary, Junior and senior High Schools are lacking of trained and qualified teachers within the entire konobo administrative district. Because of this many parents are feeling reluctant to send their children to school and many of them don't have the financial capabilities to send their kids to the city for schooling. At the end results, many of the children spent the rest of the day home or ends up staying on the farms with their parents for the whole day.

issuedescription: There are no medical facilities within the entire Gbardru Chiefdom. Pregnant women, sick men and women, both young and old have to walked seven to eight hours to seek medical attentions. As a results, some pregnant women even give birth on the way. Because of the long distances, many people prefer buying drugs from the bucket from petty drugs trader. Many of the time, these drugs had expired because of the long exposure to sunlight which they have no knowledge about.
statusnotes: There are no medical facilities within the entire Gbardru Chiefdom. Pregnant women, sick men and women, both young and old have to walked seven to eight hours to seek medical attentions. As a results, some pregnant women even give birth on the way. Because of the long distances, many people prefer buying drugs from the bucket from petty drugs trader. Many of the time, these drugs had expired because of the long exposure to sunlight which they have no knowledge about.

CF members, J.Dahnty Slangon and Mary Louh will facilitate the referral to the DSC on September 8, 2016
issuedescription:
Reports submitted  by several CF members during the September 6 meeting in Garplay asserted that a deadly snack society has been launched by some youth of Gbelay-Geh District thereby threatening non-members’ lives.
It is said that members of this society are   usually hired by politicians and big business people to get at their opponents by poisoning them in drinks and food.
Couple of the society members have been arrested by traditional leaders of the district and have confessed their involvement and have offered to undergo a traditional oath to denounce further participation in this harmful snack society, while others have refused to undergo the oath because of lack of money to facilitate the oath process. An accused person, under the traditional rule of the district has to pay an oath fee of LD5000.00

issuedescription: Security actors on the Kparblee DSC reported at the September 8 meeting that citizens of Kaylay town on the Liberian side of the Liberian-Ivorian border and Toyeblee, a town on the Ivorian side across the Cestos River are in a serious dispute over the use of a ferry constructed by the people of Kaylay.The Ivorian argue that the ferry constructed by Kaylay is not save for human transportation and should be grounded off the Cestos River.  The people of Kaylay have refused to accept the Ivorian argument on grounds that the people of Kaylay feel that the Ivoirians are doing this for economic reason but not because of poor condition on the Kaylay ferry.
issuename: Conflict over ferry in Karblee district

actionplandescription: Elevate issue to the NSC on Aug.30, 2016
issuedescription:
"LDEA and LNFS have repeatedly reported about their incapacity to deploy across the whole of Lofa due to shortage of manpower and lack of mobility. They said their current manpower size in the county is five and out of that figure, one is currently seriously sick. They are worried over the drawdown of UNMIL who has over the years provided them with technical and logistical assistances. LNFS has repeatedly reported about the lack of fire respond equipment & station in the county leaving the whole county particular Voinjama vulnerable to fire disaster. They recorded over 10 fire incidents which resulted to loss of lives and valuable properties across the county during last dry season. They are now calling on government to institute measures that will prevent reoccurrence. The Superintendent however assured LNFS provision of land space for the construction of fire station in Voinjama as soon as arrangements are concluded with City Cooperation. LNFS has also repeatedly reported about shortage of manpower in the county thereby limiting their presence to only Voinjama District and leaving the rest of the districts vulnerable
"
issuename: LDEA and LNFS shortage of manpower and logistics for effective operations

issuedescription: The sheriff of the Foya Magisterial Court, referred to as Mr. Amos is reported of been in the constant habit of brutally effecting arrest in the Foya and its environs. According to the DSC and CF members in Foya, Mr. Amos always goes about torturing accused when ever he goes to effect an arrest. The public has gotten irritated by his unmannered behavior and has reported his action to the Foya DSC for immediate intervention or resort to violence if DSC fails to intervene timely.

Security Actors are contemplating on deciding timeline for motorcyclists movement especially at nights ASAP

issuedescription: On Sunday, September 11, 2016 a motorcyclist known as Mohammed Swaray, 19yrs, Mandingo, a Liberian from Vonema Town, Voinjama District was murdered allegedly  by two perpetrators – Zubah Boiboi Kalivougui, 28yrs, Lorma, a Guinean and Forkpah Sumowood, 42yrs, Lorma, a Liberian from Duogomai Town, Voinjama District. The two of them have been arrested and currently behind bar. According to Police source, these two men allegedly killed Mohammed Swaray in order to take ownership of his motorbike and for subsequent sale to Guinea. The incident occurred between Kolograzu and Kpangbamai Towns in Voinjama District.

statusnotes: The Check Point is in the middle of  Toe Town which can cause distractions to security officers assigned to the check point. And many people take advantage of bypassing the check point.

In addressing these concerns, the DSC considered counts 2 & 3 as issues that require the attention of higher structure. Demanding and forcibly taking money from lawful business people at an international frontier by security officers is a crime under Liberian Laws and therefore needs the involvement of the county security council to address it diplomatically.

actionplandescription: To address this issue, the DSC elevated it to the CSC where the head of all women groups in Nimba is a member. In addressing herself to the issue, madam Yah Belleh, coordinator of women in Nimba confirmed that Annie Weh is still the legitimate leader of the Bu-Yao women
issuedescription:
During the launch of MLDL in Bu-Yao District in 2013, madam Annie Weh was presented by district authority as the leader of Bu-Yao women and was admitted to the membership of the Bu-Yao DSC.
 Of late, a lady called madam Margret roe launched a campaign against Annie that the women of Bu-Yao have selected her as the new leader of Bu -Yao women. This concern was bitterly contested by Annie.
issuename: leadership crises in the women leadership of Bu-Yao District.

The G-CF looks forward to feedback from the DSC at the November meeting.
issuedescription: G-CF members from border communities reported that the border town of Gornortonwin has a wide border crossing point without any state security assigned. The report stated that most business people use this point unchecked. The CF members fear that some unscrupulous business people could use this unprotected crossing point to input arms and other harmful substances into the country, especially as we approach elections season in Liberia.
issuename: G-CF members from border communities reported that the border town of Gornortonwin has a wide border crossing point without any state security assigned

issuedescription: Konobo District commissioner does not have a clerk.The clerk should be the secretary of the DSC. As the result they always delay in making reports.
statusnotes: There is no clerk for the Konobo district commissioner.This is creating problem for the DSC  especially when it comes to the operation of the DSC.The clerk is usually the Secretary for the DSC and should be on Government pay roll  but it is not in the case with Konobo district.

actionplandescription:
Briefing members of the CSC, the chairman, Mr. Fong Zuagele asserted that there is a budget line in the 2016-2017 national budget of Liberia called the rubber sector development fund. This is the fund government is planning to use to alleviate the claims of the workers when the budget passes in early October, 2016.
The CSC chairman added that this information had never been given to the workers, citing lack of adequate information sharing with the workers as root cause of the disputes.
He promised to provide the necessary information to the workers and will appeal to them to allow him engage authority of the ministry of finance and development planning for said fund. The government needs US 900,000.00 to settle about 600 aggrieved workers of cocopa
issuedescription:
Nimba County Security Council has extended invitation to the leadership of the Cocopa Workers’ union for a conference to discuss their grievances on October 17, 2016 in Sanniquellie.
The invitation was prompted by a press release issued by the president of the cocopa workers’ union, Mr. Sarkpah Mah that following many failed promises by the management of Nimba Rubber Corporation, (interim management Team) and the Nimba Legislative Caucus, the workers were left with no other alternatives but to draw the attention of the central government by planning a violent demonstration which was halted as a result of the CSC’s invitation.
issuename: Cocopa workers threaten to set road block again

actionplandescription: The acting manager also reported that despite government moratorium on diamond and gold mining in the country, the aggrieved workers are alleged to be involved in mining of gold and diamond in the cocopa concession area.
issuedescription:
The acting manager of the Nimba Rubber Corporation, Mr. Alfred Gaye reported to the CSC that aggrieved workers of Cocopa have been seen in recent months doing illegal rubber tapping on the plantation. Proceeds from tapping are shared by aggrieved workers to sustain themselves.
The acting manager also reported that despite government moratorium on diamond and gold mining in the country, the aggrieved workers are alleged to be involved in mining of gold and diamond in the cocopa concession area.
issuename: Illegal mining and rubber tapping in Cocopa

actionplandescription: According to the report, LDEA agents assigned in the district got intelligence that the school principal was dealing in drugs. Based on the information, the LDEA prayed for search warrant from the Bahn Magisterial Court to search all homes in Boe-Kparplay town. The court granted the warrant and during the search, the quantity of the drugs mentioned above was found and seized by LDEA.
issuedescription: The county commander of the Liberia Drugs Enforcement Agency (LDEA), Col. Julius Kanubah reported to the CSC that the principal of Boe-Kparplay public school located in Boe-Quella administrative District, Mr. Stephen Toweh, the younger brother of representative, Ricks Toweh of electoral district # 6 was found with 200 kg of marijuana in his bed room.

actionplandescription: LDEA officers argued that Stephen be properly bonded before the Bahn Magisterial Court by any qualified persons other than representative Toweh because under the laws of Liberia, a sitting representative is not qualified to practice law in any court of competent jurisdiction in the republic. CSC is following up on this case
issuedescription: A member of the House of Representatives for Nimba County Electoral District # 6, Hon Ricks Toweh who is also the eldest brother of the accused school principal was reported to have obstructed the arrest and prosecution of Stephen in Bahn Magisterial Court by LDEA officers on ground that he (Ricks) is the legal counsel for Stephen and will keep Stephen until the court gets ready for the hearing..

actionplandescription:
The LFA holds fear that as we go closer to 2017 presidential and Legislative elections more violence is eminent because politicians will use soccer tournaments to solicit support of the youth who constitute about 75 % of the voting population in Liberia.
The LFA also used the meeting to appeal to the CSC to support an anti-mob violence awareness campaign in Nimba before the situation grows to an uncontrollable proportion. CSC promised to study the situation and come out with plans to address the request soon.
issuedescription:
The chairman of the county committee of the Liberia Football Association (LFA) Mr. Floyd S. Tomah reported to the CSC that over the past few months, soccer tournaments organized by politicians who are seeking support of youth through sports have ended in violent confrontations in some cases leaving several players wounded.
Recent incidents in point include:
1.	Yourpea Old  and  New Towns  where the violence degenerated into burning houses and destroying farms following serious disagreement on the field of play during a soccer match 
2.	Gban and Kpoapa towns where the violence escalated to the use of   single barrel guns resulting to injury of several player and spectators and 
3.	Larpea # 1 and Loelay Towns where the violence led to a player’s left leg being broken by angry mob supporting Larpea # 1 soccer team.
issuename: Soccer games turned into violent confrontation in Nimba County

actionplancommittee: Mr. Thomas S. Gonotee, Zargbaye Kehwillian and Jonathan Dugbo were assigned to make follow-up on the Karrn River bridge with the CSC
actionplandescription: Mr. Thomas S. Gonotee, Zargbaye Kehwillian and Jonathan Dugbo were assigned to make follow-up on the Karrn River bridge with the CSC while Lyndon Johnson, Samuel Gono, Sannie Gongba and Othello Zomonway were assigned to meet with AML management to address the issue of transportation of iron ore on public road passing through towns and villages with school children and commercial vehicles using the same route. These committees are scheduled to report outcomes of their intervention at the November meeting.
issuedescription:
The Yarmein DSC and Bonlah Community Forum joint regular meeting was held in Camp # 4 on October 5, 2016 to discuss community security concerns affecting the people of Yarmein District.
During separate session of the DSC three key issues were discussed, one of which have been resolve. The issues  include:
1.	Damaged Kahn River bridge
2.	Illegal planting of crops on AML concession and 
3.	AML’s plan to transport Iron Ore on public road in tricks.

actionplandescription: These committees are scheduled to report outcomes of their intervention at the November meeting
issuedescription: Lyndon Johnson, Samuel Gono, Sannie Gongba and Othello Zomonway were assigned to meet with AML management to address the issue of transportation of iron ore on public road passing through towns and villages with school children and commercial vehicles using the same route
issuename: 2.	Illegal planting of crops on AML concession

actionplandescription: These committees are scheduled to report outcomes of their intervention at the November meeting.
issuedescription:
During separate session of the DSC three key issues were discussed, one of which have been resolve. The issues  include:
1.	Damaged Kahn River bridge
2.	Illegal planting of crops on AML concession and 
3.	AML’s plan to transport Iron Ore on public road in tricks.
Following the intervention of a DSC committee headed by Paramount Chief Cooper Walakah, towns around the AML mining area were advised to desist from planting crops on mining concession area contracted by AML from the government of Liberia for 25 years.
Local authorities of the towns promised to advise their respective citizens to respect provisions of the 25 years agreement between the Liberian Government and AML.
The other two concerns were reflagged and assigned to two new committees.
Mr. Thomas S. Gonotee, Zargbaye Kehwillian and Jonathan Dugbo were assigned to make follow-up on the Karrn River bridge with the CSC while Lyndon Johnson, Samuel Gono, Sannie Gongba and Othello Zomonway were assigned to meet with AML management to address the issue of transportation of iron ore on public road passing through towns and villages with school children and commercial vehicles using the same route. These committees are scheduled to report outcomes of their intervention at the November meeting.
issuename: 3.	AML’s plan to transport Iron Ore on public road in tricks.

actionplandescription: In an attempt to address the issue, the leadership of the Bonlah Community Forum constituted a five person committee to meet the management of AML to discuss possible relocation of the dump site to a safer place outside of the community center. The committee will report on the outcome of their meeting at the November meeting.
issuedescription: CF members from Yekepa community where AML mine workers are based reported that the company has established a dump site in the center of the community posing serious health hazard for inhabitants of Yekepa.The report pointed out that the dump site is located near Area-P market where food items are sold for human consumption.
issuename: The company has established a dump site in the center of the community posing serious health hazard for inhabitants of Yekepa.

 Lt. Darius Bomah and C. Gonkarnue Karnue were designated to meet families of mad people in Saclepea to advise them take their affected children to the nearest health centers for treatment.
issuedescription:
On October 12, 2016, the joint monthly meeting of the Wee-Gbeyi DSC and Fleedin CF was held in Fleedin town.
 Issues identified and  discussed by W-DSC during its separate session  were:
1.	Parking of heavy duty trucks on the shoulders of narrow streets in Saclepea
2.	Increase in the presence of  mad people in Saclepea City
3.	Illegal check points erected by youth on the Ganta-Tappiota high way
issuename: 1.	Parking of heavy duty trucks on the shoulders of narrow streets in Saclepea

actionplandescription:
The third committee was instructed by the leadership of the Wee-Gbeyi DSC to  meet LNP authorities in Salepea City  to discuss the  issue of youth erecting arbitrary  check points  at areas  where  the Ganta-Tappita highway has road damages to collect fee  from vehicle owners  who get caught in  muddy areas.
These committees will report at the joint structure meeting in November.

actionplandescription: The F-CF leadership constituted a 4 persons committee to raise awareness among citizens and residents of the town and its surrounding communities on the criminal implications such behavior poses on the integrity of people who are perceived to be future leaders of the countr
issuedescription:
The Fleedin Community Forum separate session deliberations, it was able to identify and discussed two key security concerns that were brought before it by CF members from Nyanyee and Guan towns.
The  concerns were:
1.	An upsurge in rubber theft in Nyanyee town by unknown people.
2.	Land dispute between Edwin Nyan of Blapa and Sabatoe Meayean of Guan town.
issuename: 1.	An upsurge in rubber theft in Nyanyee town by unknown people.

community: Dehjelah, Peah, Delayee and Droglor Towns
actionplandescription: The CF intervention committee will hold meetings with those affected communities and encourage them to dig wells in their communities.
issuedescription: There are no safe drinking water in many towns due to the damages of hand pumps in those communities.
statusnotes: There are no safe drinking water in many towns due to the damages of hand pumps in those communities.

community: Peah, Sayou-o, Sentrodu and Boundary Towns
actionplandescription: CF intervention committee members to meet with the District Education Officer requesting him to do a draft letter to the Minister of education to send more teacher to the district.
issuedescription: Many Junior and Senior high schools within konobo administrative are lacking of trained and qualify school teachers. Many times students sat in their various classes for the whole day without seeing a single teacher.
statusnotes: Many Junior and Senior high schools within konobo administrative are lacking of trained and qualify school teachers. Many times students sat in their various classes for the whole day without seeing a single teacher.

actionplandescription: Referred to the DSC
issuedescription: All of the motor roads within konobo district are currently in terrible conditions due to heavy rain falls. All of the roads are very muddy and slippery.
statusnotes: All of the motor roads within konobo district are currently in terrible conditions due to heavy rain falls. All of the roads are very muddy and slippery.

community: Sayuo Town, Tuglor Town and Wulu Town
actionplandescription: Referred to the DSC
issuedescription: Many of the hand pumps in the district that were providing clean and safe drinking water are damage and can't be repair because of the lack of spare parts. Many of the inhabitants living in those affected communities are now drinking from creek water.
statusnotes: Many of the hand pumps in the district that were providing clean and safe drinking water are damage and can't be repair because of the lack of spare parts. Many of the inhabitants living in those affected communities are now drinking from creek water.

disputant: Residents of Peace community vs well owner
actionplandescription: To order the owner of the well to close/cover the well | October 13, 2016
issuedescription: On August 30, 2016, a boy by the name of Isaac Masalay got drown in an open well at Peace Community within Foya City. The incident has broutht about serious problem for the residents for that community and the owner of the well.
issuename: Open well poses risk to the lives of residents of the Peace community and it environment.

disputant: Residents of Foya City vs criminals
actionplancommittee: The Joint security of Foya District
actionplandescription: To make a search for those criminals and to arrest and jail them | Oct 15. 2016
issuedescription: Early September 2016, some nortorious criminals who were once in Foya years back are being seen on the streets of Foy again. Residents of Foya City including some victems of those nortorious criminals are raising serious concern with local authorities to put in place some mechanism in handling the setuation.
issuename: Threat of increase in crime rate as nortorious criminals are found in the streets of Foya City

disputant: Radio Tamba Taikor vs. Residents of Foya District
actionplancommittee: The District authorities, Superintendent, Paranmount Chief and Commissioner
actionplandescription: To prevail on the Vice President again to cover the cost of the transmiter | Oct 22, 2016
issuedescription: Since May 2016, the only radio station, Radio Tamba Taikor in Foya District has been off the air waves as a result of lightening strack that led to damaging the only trasmitor that cost more than three housand United States dollars. The Management of the radio station and most residents of Foya District continue to call on the local authorities and national Government to provide support in getting their only radion station on at this critical moment of up comming 2017 national elections
issuename: The only community radio station, Radio Tamba Taikor in Foya District is off air for the past five (5) months.

actionplancommittee: FDA with support from the County authority
actionplandescription: The FDA to move in both locations and provide fact findings | Oct 27, 2016
issuedescription: It is reported that two hunters have died as a result of an alledge attack by elephants in two different communities (Letisu and Kpademai) within Voinjama District. It is alledge that the hunter from Letisu was running after mokeys when he came across an elephant baby but got killed by the elephant baby's mother that attacked the hunter. His body was discovered by his friend hunter after the death incident.
issuename: Hunters at risk against Elephant attack in the Lofa forest

disputant: unregistered fire arm users vs. citizens of Lofa
actionplancommittee: The County authorities including all Commissioners and Paranmount Chieves
actionplandescription: All fire arms users to register their guns. The Process to commence not later than | Nov 15,  2016
issuedescription: The use of unregistered small arms (especially single barrow guns) is on the increase within Lofa County and have claimed the attention of peaceful citizens of the County. It has also been noticed that most of the users of these weapons are hunters from villages accross Lofa County. The CSC is recommending registeration of fire arms to keep track owners for easy reference.
issuename: Increase in  unregistered fire arms in Lofa County

actionplancommittee: The BIN along with the Commerce Officers
actionplandescription: The Commerce Office to investigate issue and take necessary actions on or before November 1, 2016
issuedescription: Illegal exporting of Cocoa produce by unidentified business individuals along with a truck load of Cocoa traveling  through Liberia – Sierra Leone border by way of Foya was arrested during the early part of October. The issue was arrested by the BIN and turned over to the Commerce officer in Foya City pending investigation.

actionplandescription: The BIN to ensure that all aliens without proper document be sent back to their Country with immediate effect
issuedescription: During the month of October this year, a high influx of aliens into Lofa (including children)  through the Liberian, Guinean and Sierra Leonean borders is being experienced as reported by BIN and MRU representative. It is said that most of the aliens are found in locations within Liberia contrary to their documents issued at the borders. For instance, some are having document that says they are paying visit to extended family member to a border town only to find them in Voinjama, Foya or Kolahun doing business or living with some else. The BIN also complain that when some of the travelers, especially the Liberians are traveling with kids, they are inpatient to go through the protocol of detecting if the legitimate parent.
issuename: High influx of aliens into Lofa County
